Regional Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 42066  
April 2008 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Supporting the Third High-Level Forum on Aid 
Effectiveness and its Preparatory Consultation 
Process
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
    AAA    –  Accra Agenda for Action 
ADB    –  Asian Development Bank 
    CoP-MfDR  –  Community of Practice on Management for 
Development Results 
    DMC    –  developing member country 
    HLF-2   –  Second High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness 
HLF-3  –  Third High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness 
OECD–DAC  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and  
Development–Development Assistance Committee 
RETA    –  regional technical assistance 
SPPI    –  Strategy, Planning, Policy, and Inter-Agency Relations  
      Division of ADB 
UNDP   –  United Nations Development Programme 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification   –  General intervention 
Sectors  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsectors      –  Economic management 
Themes      –  Regional cooperation, sustainable economic growth 
Subthemes      –  Promoting macroeconomic stability, organizational 
development  
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Managing Director General  R. Nag, Office of the Managing Director General 
Director General  K. Sakai, Strategy and Policy Department (SPD) 
Senior Director  C.  MacCormac,  Strategic  Planning,  Policy  and  Interagency 
  Relations Division, SPD 
   
Team leader  B. Purdue, Head, Results Management Unit, SPD 
Team members  A. Ressano-Garcia, Planning and Policy Specialist, SPD 
M. Senapaty, Senior Planning and Policy Specialist, SPD 
S. Zahid, Principal Planning and Policy Specialist, SPD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)1has  been  prepared  to  facilitate  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) support for the Third High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness (HLF-3) 
on 2–4 September 2008 in Accra, Ghana, and for the effective participation of developing 
member countries (DMCs) in preparatory events leading to it. This RETA also represents ADB’s 
ongoing commitment to the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness (the Paris Declaration), as 
expressed by the President at the Second High-Level Forum (HLF-2) in Paris in March 2005, 
and  as  reaffirmed  at  the  Third  International  Roundtable  on  Management  for  Development 
Results held in Hanoi in February 2007. The HLF-3 will be one of the key items for discussion at 
the coming meeting of heads of multilateral development banks on 14 April 2008 in Washington, 
DC. In the lead-up to the HLF-3, key multilateral and bilateral donors have agreed to hold 
preparatory events to (i) enable broader input and ownership of the agenda, (ii) collect best-
practice examples and remaining challenges, and (iii) develop momentum toward a concrete 
outcome for HLF-3, notably through the articulation of the Accra Agenda for Action (AAA). The 
RETA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  The RETA was conceptualized following ADB's participation in the Organisation for 
Economic Co-operation and Development–Development Assistance Committee (OECD-DAC) 
Working Party on Aid Effectiveness Meeting on 28–29 November 2007 in Paris. Based on a 
background  document  entitled  Background  Information  on  Accra  High  Level  Forum 
(Supplementary Appendix), the meeting held preliminary discussions on the preparations to be 
made for the HLF-3. This document laid out concept notes for the several key items of the HLF-
3 including the (i) marketplace, (ii) regional consultation process, (iii) reporting from Accra, and 
(iv) communications strategy. Since then, these items continue to be discussed in more detail at 
the regular meetings of the HLF-3 steering committee. 
 
3.  The RETA follows from the abovementioned background document of the OECD-DAC 
as well as from ADB’s own consultation with other donors by videoconference and with partner 
countries during a Regional Workshop on the Paris Declaration Survey 2008 in Bangkok on 21–
22 January 2008. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  The international community is committed to helping Asia and Pacific region partner 
countries meet the Millennium Development Goals by 2015. Providing more effective aid and 
improving its impact on development are important contributions to this end. 
 
5.  The development community has been working to enhance aid effectiveness through the 
First  High-Level  Forum  held  in  Rome  in  2003,  which  identified  a  general  framework  for 
harmonization and alignment, and the HLF-2, which produced the Paris Declaration. More than 
100 partner and donor countries and international agencies endorsed the Paris Declaration, a 
framework of discrete commitments and indicators of progress—including targets for ownership, 
alignment,  harmonization,  managing  for  results,  and  mutual  accountability—to  improve  aid 
effectiveness. With this endorsement, Asia and Pacific region partner countries and donors 
committed to monitor country implementation of the Paris Declaration. 
 
6.  ADB  has  been  active in  the  development  community  and  in supporting  global and 
regional efforts toward enhancing aid effectiveness.  
                                                 
1  The TA was first listed in ADB Business Opportunities on 22 February 2008.

2     
 (i)  ADB  was  the  main  sponsor  and  organizer  of  the  Asia  and  Pacific  regional 
consultation  workshops  for  the  HLF-2  (in  Bangkok  in  October  2004  and  in 
Bishkek in November 2004) and a key sponsor of, and an active participant at, 
the  HLF-2  in  Paris  in  March  2005,  which  led  to  the  signing  of  the  Paris 
Declaration.  
(ii)  Since Paris, ADB has been very active in promoting the debate on the monitoring 
and evaluation of the Paris Declaration. ADB hosted and organized the Asia-
Pacific Regional Forum on Aid Effectiveness in Manila on October 2006, which 
dealt with the implementation of the Paris Declaration in the region. ADB also 
cosponsored the Orientation Workshop on the Paris Declaration 2008 Monitoring 
Survey in Bangkok in January 2008.  
(iii)  ADB  was  a  key  sponsor  of,  and  an  active  participant  at,  the  international 
roundtables on results in Marrakesh in February 2004 and in Hanoi in February 
2007 and has been since 2005 the sponsor and facilitator for the Community of 
Practice on Management for Development Results (CoP-MfDR) in the Asia and 
Pacific region.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The proposed RETA will contribute to global efforts to improve the effectiveness of 
development  assistance  by  supporting  the  implementation  of  the  five  pillars  of  the  Paris 
Declaration: harmonization, alignment, ownership, management for development results, and 
mutual accountability. The RETA will provide essential inputs to consolidate contributions to the 
HLF-3 from Asia and Pacific region partner countries. HLF-3 will host a marketplace on aid 
effectiveness  for  Asia  and  Pacific  region  partner  countries,  roundtables  to  discuss  various 
aspects of the aid effectiveness agenda, and a ministerial forum that will endorse the AAA to 
enhance and improve the implementation of Paris commitments. 
 
8.   The proposed RETA aims to 
 (i)  disseminate  country-based  knowledge  and  experiences  about  development 
effectiveness, including the implementation of the Paris Declaration, which will 
provide a sound basis for discussions at the HLF-3;  
(ii)  provide inputs into the preparation of the draft AAA and facilitate discussions at 
the HLF-3 roundtables; 
(iii)  help selected DMCs prepare inputs for the marketplace and raise awareness in 
DMCs about best practices to enhance development effectiveness, including 
harmonization, alignment, ownership, management for development results, and 
mutual accountability; and 
(iv)  sponsor the HLF-3, including contributions to the pooled fund to cover costs for 
Asia and Pacific region partner countries’ participation. 
 
9.  The expected outputs are 
 (i)  four  subregional  workshops  to  be  jointly  organized  with  other  development 
partners; 
(ii)  timely inputs into the draft AAA and into the preparation, agenda, and scope for 
HLF-3 roundtables; 
(iii)  a  website  for  posting  comments  and  proposals  regarding  aid  effectiveness 
including CoP-MfDR issues;

3 
(iv)  a single document consolidating all inputs from the subregional workshops and 
website to provide a regional perspective and input towards discussions at HLF-3; 
(v)  two regional meetings of the members of CoP-MfDR to be organized by ADB; 
and 
(vi)   the participation of DMCs, including representatives of CoP-MfDR, at the HLF-3, 
including the roundtable meetings, ministerial-level sessions, and marketplace. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The four subregional workshops will be as follows: 
(i)  Pacific subregion: Fiji Islands, 4–7 April 2008 (Cook Islands, Federated States of 
Micronesia,  Fiji  Islands,  Kiribati,  Nauru,  Niue,  Papua  New  Guinea,  Palau, 
Republic of the Marshall Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and 
Vanuatu); 
(ii)  Southeast Asia: Bangkok, 21–22 April 2008 (Cambodia, People’s Republic of 
China,  Indonesia,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  Malaysia,  Philippines, 
Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Viet Nam); 
(iii)  South Asia: Bangkok, 5–6 May 2008 (Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, 
Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka); and 
(iv)  Central and West Asia: Bangkok, 8–9 May 2008 (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, 
Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Mongolia,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and 
Uzbekistan). 
 
11.  The key objectives of the subregional workshops will be to (i) consult on the AAA draft 
(to be made available towards end of March), (ii) discuss how countries can best contribute to 
the nine roundtables of the HLF-3, (iii) discuss preparing partner country participation at the 
HLF-3 marketplace, and (iv) contribute to an Asia and Pacific region perspectives document to 
be tabled at HLF-3. 
  
12.  Regarding participation, the workshops will bring together the following:  
 (i)  Asia and Pacific region partner countries: a total of four or five government 
representatives from each DMC including the national coordinator for the 2008 
Paris Declaration monitoring survey; two from policy ministries (finance, planning, 
and/or foreign affairs) and two from line (sectoral) ministries (the DMC delegation 
should include at least one senior official); 
(ii)  donors:  participation  limited  to  organizers  and  sponsors  of  the  workshops, 
OECD-DAC, and donor focal points in each DMC (identified for the 2008 Paris 
Declaration monitoring survey); and 
(iii)  civil society: a total of three or four country-level representatives of civil society 
organizations in each workshop drawn from civil society participants at previous 
regional and global consultations on HLF-3. 
 
13.  A summary of discussions from each subregional workshop will be drafted and a follow-
up consolidated report will be prepared by a consultant. This report will aim to bring to the HLF-
3 an Asia and Pacific regional perspective on aid effectiveness and the implementation of the 
Paris Declaration. 
 
14.  ADB will manage a website from late April to September 2008 to allow further discussion 
and proposals for comments on the consolidated report and specific topics of the HLF-3. This 
ADB website will be linked to the official HLF-3 website, which will also be launched in April 
2008.

4     
 
15.  ADB will organize a regional gathering of CoP-MfDR members at a location and date to 
be determined to craft partner country inputs on MfDR for the HLF-3. This meeting will (i) review 
and debate the Paris Declaration progress report and the draft AAA before they are finalized, (ii) 
consider inputs into the MfDR debate at the HLF-3, (iii) identify case studies in MfDR for Accra, 
and (iv) discuss ways to showcase the potential of the CoP-MfDR for sustainable capacity 
development in MfDR. 
 
16.  In collaboration with the HLF-3 Roundtable on MfDR, ADB will convene an abbreviated 
CoP-MfDR meeting in Accra in parallel to the HLF-3 in September 2008 to provide a platform for 
the Asia and Pacific region partner countries to be heard regarding results management. 
 
17.  ADB will also assist DMCs (including CoP-MfDR members) in their participation at the 
HLF-3. This assistance will be two-fold: (i) financing the travel and accommodation costs of a 
considerable number (25–30) of DMC delegates and (ii) assisting, through local consultants, 
certain DMCs in their participation in the marketplace of the HLF-3. 
 
18.  Certain post-HLF-3 activities will also be considered: (i) the dissemination of messages 
from Accra through the web, newsletters, publications, or CD-ROMs and (ii) the organization of 
other types of activities needed for a follow-up process to the HLF-3 in the region. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
19.  The  total  amount  of  the  RETA,  which  is  estimated  at  $500,000  equivalent,  will  be 
financed as a grant from ADB’s technical assistance funding program. It is proposed that, 
through this RETA, ADB provide $190,000 to finance the subregional workshops for the Pacific, 
Southeast Asia, South Asia, and Central Asia.2 ADB will contribute this fund to a pool managed 
by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). This will be done through the signing 
of an administrative arrangement between ADB and UNDP as set by the memorandum of 
understanding between them.3  
 
20.  The  total cost  of  the CoP-MfDR  consultation  process  towards  the HLF-3,  including 
DMCs’ participation at Accra, is estimated at $150,000, which ADB will finance entirely. 
 
21.  ADB will also provide $160,000 toward organizing the HLF-3 in Accra. These funds will 
be allocated mainly toward financing the participation of DMCs.4 The detailed cost estimates are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  Given the fact that four sub-regional consultation meetings need to be organized and 
given the good working partnership established with the UNDP Regional Center in Bangkok, 
ADB will host 3 of the workshops in Bangkok, Thailand. The remaining workshop will be held in 
                                                 
2  The remaining balance of the total workshop cost will be shouldered by other donors, mainly UNDP, Government of 
Japan, and the World Bank, which have indicated interest in cosponsoring all four workshops. 
3  On 23 July 2007, ADB and UNDP signed a memorandum of understanding that covers cofinancing and other 
arrangements for funding regional, subregional, and country programs and projects.  
4  Prior to finalizing the RETA paper, ADB’s Board of Directors approved on 31 March 2008, on a no-objection basis, 
a  Board waiver to procurement from a non-ADB member country, in accordance with Article 14 (ix) of the Charter, 
to finance the participation of DMC delegations in the Third High-Level Forum in Accra, Ghana, on 2–4 September 
2008.

5 
the Fiji Islands, where the Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat and the UNDP Pacific Center have 
taken  the  initiative  to  organize  the  consultations.  Two  meetings  of  the  CoP-MfDR  will  be 
organized and hosted by ADB: one at ADB headquarters in Manila and the other in Accra, 
Ghana, at the venue of the HLF-3.  
 
23.  The  RETA  implementation  period  is  scheduled  for  9  months,  from  April  2008  to 
December 2008. ADB will be the Executing Agency. ADB’s Strategy and Policy Department, 
specifically the Strategy, Planning, Policy, and Inter-Agency Relations Division and the Results 
Management Unit will administer the RETA in cooperation with ADB's Resident Mission in 
Thailand and the Pacific Subregional Office in Suva, Fiji Islands. An international consultant will 
be engaged to prepare individual reports from each subregional workshop, which will be tabled 
and facilitate discussions at the HLF-3 in Accra, Ghana. Another international consultant will be 
engaged to edit a consolidated regional perspective document. National consultants will be 
engaged to achieve the expected outputs for the HLF-3, namely to (i) facilitate the regional 
consultations, (ii) set up and maintain a website, and (iii) assist DMCs’ participation in the HLF-3 
marketplace. An outline of the terms of reference for the consultants is in Appendix 3. ADB will 
engage the consultants on an individual basis and in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) and other arrangements satisfactory to 
ADB for engaging consultants. A no objection letter will be obtained from those DMCs in which 
activities specifically related to that DMC will be conducted.  
 
24.  ADB’s regional departments will be involved in organizing the workshops. In addition, the 
preparation of any necessary materials for the consultations will be done in close coordination 
with the regional departments.  
 
25.  To ensure timely and effective dissemination of results and deliverables from these 
subregional workshops, plans are in place to ensure that the consolidated report and the 
summaries of discussions at the subregional workshops will be disseminated to DMCs and 
other development institutions. These reports will also be distributed at the HLF-3. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
supporting the Third High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness and its Preparatory Consultation 
Process, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Technical Writer (international, 2 person-months) 
 
1.  An internationally recruited consultant with expertise in writing strategic planning and 
policy development documents will render 2 person-month of services. The consultant will be 
responsible for preparing individual reports for the three subregional workshops taking place in 
Bangkok  in  close  coordination  with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  staff  in  the  Strategic 
Planning, Policy, and Interagency Division (SPPI) and the other organizers of the workshops:  
Government of Japan, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and World Bank. The 
consultant will be based in Bangkok, Thailand, and his or her tasks will include  
(i)  participating in the subregional workshops in Bangkok and acting as resource 
person if necessary, 
(ii)   reviewing concept notes and technical papers prepared by other agencies and 
providing  comprehensive  comments  to  improve  the  quality  of  the  final 
documents, and 
(iii)   collecting notes from the workshop rapporteur and preparing a summary report 
based on them for each workshop. 
 
B.  Technical Editor (international, 1 person-month) 
 
2.  An internationally recruited consultant with expertise in editing strategic planning and 
policy development documents will render 1 person-month of services. The consultant will work 
closely  with  SPPI  and  be  responsible  for  finalizing  the  consolidated  regional  perspective 
document. The tasks of the consultant will include 
(i)  reorganizing text so that the subject matter is easy to understand; 
(ii)  rephrasing text to tighten it , make it flow, and reduce ambiguity; 
(iii)  writing text where required to ensure the flow and readability of the paper; 
(iv)  reviewing  an  edited  manuscript  for  spelling,  grammar,  consistency,  format, 
completeness, and accuracy regarding text, tables, bibliographies, references, 
and footnotes; 
(v)  recasting and editing tables and figures; 
(vi)  spotting obvious errors, including in mathematical calculations, and pointing out 
questionable proper names, bibliographic references, and the like (but not fact 
checking);  
(vii)  ensuring that the text conforms to the ADB Handbook of Style and Usage;  
(viii)  editing notes to ensure that the text references are correct;  
(ix)  checking the author’s final changes; and 
(x)  consulting extensively with the author and project manager. 
 
C.  Workshop Coordinator (national, 10 person-months) 
 
3.  A national consultant will be engaged for 10 person-months to assist in the effective 
planning, coordination, and conduct of a series of outcomes from the international conference 
Asia  2015:  Promoting  Growth,  Ending  Poverty,  of  March  2005,  regarding  the  international 
agenda of aid effectiveness, in particular the activities related to preparations for the Third High-
Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness (HLF-3) in Accra, Ghana, on 2–4 September 2008. He or she 
will report to staff of SPPI and provide the following administrative support to deliver the outputs 
required to achieve the purpose of the assignment:

10  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  Provide and coordinate secretariat support during the workshops to help with 
organization  and  arrangements,  and  assist  in  documenting  the  workshop 
sessions. 
(ii)  Coordinate  all  necessary  logistical  arrangements  for  the  subregional 
workshops—including all relevant meetings, consultations, and videoconferences, 
etc.—and prepare required correspondence and respond to inquiries. 
(iii)  Set up workable arrangements with the resident missions concerned for the 
planning, execution, and monitoring of all activities relevant to the events and 
closely coordinate with them on all logistical and administrative matters. 
(iv)  Assist in consolidating and synthesizing workshop materials and reports and 
liaise with the Printing Office for the production of these materials as necessary. 
(v)  Liaise with development partners who will cosponsor the workshops (UNDP, 
Government of Japan, World Bank, and others) with regard to organization and 
arrangements, as well as to fund transfers, and coordinate the preparation of 
necessary letters of agreement for sharing expenses. 
 
D.  Communication Expert (national, 1 person-month)  
 
4.  A national consultant will be engaged intermittently for a cumulative maximum of 1 
month to set up and maintain a website for the HLF-3. The consultant must be experienced in 
conducting web-based internal and external consultations on institutional changes. He or she 
must  be  proficient  in analyzing  feedback  from  individuals  and  presenting  conclusions  in  a 
systematic and coherent manner that is both informative and useful to decision-makers. The 
consultant  will  preferably  have  had  previous  experience  of  working  with  ADB  and  be 
knowledgeable of its current operations in developing member countries (DMCs).  
 
5.  The consultant will be responsible for the following: 
(i)  Monitor the feedback daily on both the intranet and the external website on the 
HLF-3 and report as required by the steering committee and the secretariat in a 
format useful for review, discussion, and decision making. 
(ii)  Prepare in a timely manner responses to be posted on both the external website 
and the intranet, incorporating comments from the secretariat and the steering 
committee as needed. 
(iii)  Post in a timely manner new information on both websites as it is made available 
by the secretariat. 
(iv)  Moderate discussions on both websites and end discussions as appropriate. 
Summarize the discussions and their conclusions, if any, for the use of the 
steering committee and the secretariat. 
E.  Graphic Artist (national, 5 person-months) 
 
6.  Five national consultants will be engaged for a cumulative minimum of 1 month to assist 
DMCs  from  each  region  in  preparing  posters,  flyers,  and  other  materials  for  the  HLF-3 
marketplace. The consultant will be responsible for the following: 
(i)  Develop a standard graphic design for the DMCs’ participation in the HLF-3 
marketplace. 
(ii)  Assist ADB (SPPI and resident missions in selected DMCs) in designing posters, 
flyers, and other materials for the HLF-3 marketplace.
